text: - Hi, I'm Danilo.

I'm part of the developer
relations team at AWS
and today we're talking with Sasha.
Sasha, can you please introduce yourself

and talk about the company,
Unitary that you co-founded?
- Sure. So I'm Sasha.
I'm one of the co-founders, one of two,
and the CEO of Unitary.
And I co-founded Unitary in 2019,
so about three years old now.
And we are an online safety company,
so we're analyzing content on the internet
to check for anything harmful.

So for example, looking for
hate speech or violent content,

and we're particularly focused
on videos at the moment.

And the idea is to make the
internet a safer place for

for users and anyone who
wants to post things online.
- Oh wow. As a user of social media and
I think now having this kind of control

on user generated content is
really useful and important.

You have a PhD at the
University of Cambridge?
- [Sasha] Yes.
- Did you work with Stephen Hawking?
- [Sasha] I did.
- Wow.

- Yeah, I did my PhD on
looking at black holes

and something called
the Information Paradox.
So basically answering the question
or trying to answer the question

what happens something when
it falls into a black hole
and where does information about it go?
It was a very cool experience

and especially it was incredible
to work with Steven Hawing
who's sort of the very, very big brain

in this field and has
sort of amazing intuition.
- So what are the challenges that you face

in processing a large
amount of videos? I suppose.
- There's a lot of challenges.

I guess on the one hand,
the challenges are around
can we understand the content?
And sometimes this is almost sort of
a machine learning point of view.

Sometimes the content
and the harm associated

with the content, it's
very context dependent.

So for example, if someone puts
a caption alongside an image

or a video, it could change
the meaning quite drastically.

So we need to understand
all the sort of metadata

and surrounding content
of the video so that we

can understand the intent
of the video itself.

And is there, is this racist
or is this just a commentary
on racism, for example?

And the things we can
interpret from the video
will have profound implications
to what happens to that video?

Is it taken down or is it
just reported in some way?

- So talking about how you
analyze this video content,
what kind of content do you look into?
Video, audio, and what else?
- Sure. So, in every video
we have to take into account
sort of the visual frames of the video

as well as the audio that
comes with the videos,
that might be noises or speech.

And also often there's
extra text on the screen
or accompanying captions and comments.
And so we try and look into
all these different pieces of data

and assemble them together
to develop an understanding
of what's going on in inside that video.
- Is there anything that you want to share
on what you're working next?

- We've got lots of
exciting things coming up

and looking to look at longer
videos and live video as well

and hopefully be able to process
larger and larger volumes.
So it's really exciting.

- Thank you Sasha, for
spending some time with us
and looking forward to meeting again to

see how your company's growing
in the next six months.
- Thanks so much.
